text: Qohelet’s Investigation of Self-Indulgence

I said ⸤to myself⸥,\f + \fr 2:1 \ft Literally “to my heart” \f* “Come! I will test\f + \fr 2:1 \ft The MT reads “I will test you,” but the BHS editors propose “I will test …” Whether or not one adopts MT, Qohelet is speaking to himself \f* pleasure ⸤to see whether it is worthwhile⸥.”\f + \fr 2:1 \ft Literally “and look at goodness”; this idiom refers to the enjoyment of life \f* But look, “This also \add is\add* vanity!”
I said of laughter, “\add It is\add* folly!” and of pleasure, “⸤What does it accomplish?⸥”\f + \fr 2:2 \ft Literally “What does it give?” \f*

I also ⸤explored⸥\f + \fr 2:3 \ft Literally “I searched in my mind” \f* ⸤the effects of indulging my flesh⸥\f + \fr 2:3 \ft Literally “to cheer my flesh” \f* with wine. My mind guiding me with wisdom, ⸤I investigated⸥\f + \fr 2:3 \ft Literally “laid hold of” \f* folly so that I might discover what \add is\add* good under heaven\f + \fr 2:3 \ft Follows MT; two medieval Hebrew manuscripts, LXX, Peshitta read, “under the sun,” cf. 1:3, 9, etc. \f* for ⸤humans⸥\f + \fr 2:3 \ft Literally “the sons of the man” \f* to do ⸤during the days of their lives⸥.\f + \fr 2:3 \ft Literally “the number of the days of their lives” \f*
Qohelet’s Investigation of Personal Accomplishment
⸤I accomplished great things⸥.\f + \fr 2:4 \ft Literally “I made great my works” \f* I built for myself houses; I planted for myself vineyards.
I made for myself gardens and parks, and I planted all \add sorts of\add* fruit trees in them.
I made for myself pools of water from which to irrigate a grove of flourishing trees.
I acquired male slaves and female slaves, as well as children \add born in my\add* house. I also had livestock, cattle, and flocks more than anyone who \add was\add* before me in Jerusalem.

I also gathered to myself silver and gold—the royal and provincial treasuries. I acquired for myself male and female singers, as well as the delight of ⸤men⸥,\f + \fr 2:8 \ft Literally “the sons of the man” \f* ⸤voluptuous concubines⸥.\f + \fr 2:8 \ft Literally “a breast and breasts,” as a synecdoche for beautiful women in the king’s harem \f*
Thus, ⸤I accomplished far more⸥\f + \fr 2:9 \ft Literally “I became great and I surpassed” \f* than anyone who \add was\add* before me in Jerusalem—indeed, my wisdom stood by me.
I neither withheld anything from my eyes that they desired, nor did I deprive any pleasure from my heart. My heart rejoiced in all my toil, for this was my reward from all my toil.

Yet when I considered\f + \fr 2:11 \ft Or “turned to” \f* all the effort which I expended and the toil with which I toiled to do, then behold, “Everything \add is\add* vanity and chasing wind! There is nothing profitable under the sun!”
The Living Must Abandon the Work of their Hands to Others at Death
Next, I considered wisdom, as well as delusion and folly. What can anyone \add do\add* who will come after the king that has not already been done?
I realized that wisdom has an advantage over folly, just as light has an advantage over darkness.

⸤The wise man can see where he is walking⸥,\f + \fr 2:14 \ft Literally “The eyes of the wise \fq are \ft in his head” \f* but the fool walks in darkness. Yet I also realized that both of them suffer the same fate.

So I said ⸤to myself⸥,\f + \fr 2:15 \ft Literally “in my heart” \f* “⸤If I also suffer the same fate as the fool⸥,\f + \fr 2:15 \ft Literally “Just as the fate of the fool—so it will happen to me!” \f* ⸤what advantage is my great wisdom⸥?”\f + \fr 2:15 \ft Literally “why have I been so exceedingly wise?” \f* So I said ⸤to myself⸥,\f + \fr 2:15 \ft Literally “in my heart” \f* “This also \add is\add* vanity!”

Certainly no one will remember the wise man or the fool in ⸤future generations⸥.\f + \fr 2:16 \ft Literally “the futures” \f* When \add future\add* days come, both will have been forgotten already. How \add is it that\add* the wise man dies the same as the fool?
So I hated life because the work done under the sun \add is\add* grievous to me. For everything \add is\add* vanity and chasing wind!
So I hated all my toil with which I have toiled under the sun, for I must leave it behind to someone who will be after me.
And who knows \add whether\add* he will be wise or foolish? Yet he will exercise control of all \add the fruit of\add* my toil with which I toiled wisely under the sun. This also \add is\add* vanity!
So ⸤I began to despair⸥\f + \fr 2:20 \ft Literally “I myself turned to cause my heart to despair” \f* of all the toil with which I toiled under the sun.
For although a person may toil with great wisdom and skill, he must leave his reward to someone who has not toiled for it. This also \add is\add* vanity and a great calamity.
For what does a person receive for all his toil and in the longing of his heart with which he toils under the sun?
All his days \add are\add* painful, his labor \add brings\add* grief, and his heart cannot rest at night. This also \add is\add* vanity!
It is Best to Simply Enjoy the Passing Pleasures of Life as Reward for Pleasing God

There is nothing better for a person than to eat and drink and ⸤find delight⸥\f + \fr 2:24 \ft Literally “to see good” \f* in his toil. For I also realized that this \add is\add* from the hand of God!

For who can eat \add and drink\add*, and who can enjoy \add life\add* apart from him?\f + \fr 2:25 \ft The MT reads “more than me,” which is supported by Aramaic Targum and Latin Vulgate, but several medieval Hebrew manuscripts read “from him” \f*

For to the person who \add is\add* good in his eyes, he gives wisdom, knowledge, and joy; but to the sinner he gives the task of gathering and heaping up only to give \add it\add* to \add him who is\add* pleasing to him. This also \add is\add* vanity and chasing wind!
